quiz.title: Unit 3: Demand and Supply (Quiz 5)
quiz.subtitle: 3.5 Law of Supply: Price-Quantity Relationship for Producers (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Supply Curve, Producer Behavior, Price-Quantity Relationship, Profit Motivation

questions.question: The law of supply states that, all other factors being equal:
options: As price increases, quantity supplied decreases
As price increases, quantity supplied increases
Price and quantity supplied have no relationship
Supply remains constant regardless of price changes
questions.explanation: The law of supply describes the direct relationship between price and quantity supplied - when the price of a good rises, producers are willing to supply more, and vice versa.

questions.question: A supply curve typically slopes upward because:
options: Consumers buy less at higher prices
Higher prices make production more profitable, encouraging increased output
questions.explanation: The upward slope reflects producers' profit motivation - higher prices increase potential profits, making it worthwhile to produce more, even if it means higher production costs.

questions.question: Which of the following would cause a movement along the supply curve for wheat?
options: A change in technology for farming equipment
A change in the price of wheat
A change in the price of corn (alternative crop)
questions.explanation: A change in the good's own price causes movement along the supply curve. Changes in other factors (technology, input prices, etc.) shift the entire supply curve.

questions.question: If the market price of smartphones increases from $500 to $700, what happens to quantity supplied?
questions.explanation: According to the law of supply, a price increase leads to an increase in quantity supplied. This is movement along the supply curve, not a shift of the supply curve.

questions.question: The profit incentive is the primary reason supply curves slope upward because:
options: Higher prices allow producers to cover increasing marginal costs
Consumers always buy more at lower prices
Government subsidizes production at higher prices
Input costs decrease as production increases
questions.explanation: As production increases, marginal costs typically rise due to capacity constraints. Higher prices make it profitable to produce these additional, more expensive units.

questions.question: If production technology improves, the supply curve will:
questions.explanation: Improved technology reduces production costs, making producers willing to supply more at each price level, shifting the supply curve to the right.

questions.question: A supply schedule shows: Price $10 - Quantity 100; Price $15 - Quantity 200; Price $20 - Quantity 300. This demonstrates:
questions.explanation: This shows the direct relationship between price and quantity supplied - as price increases, quantity supplied increases, illustrating the law of supply.

questions.question: If input costs (raw materials, labor) increase, the supply curve will:
questions.explanation: Higher input costs make production more expensive, reducing the quantity producers are willing to supply at each price, shifting the supply curve to the left.

questions.question: On a standard supply curve graph, which variable is plotted on the vertical axis?
questions.explanation: In economics, price is always plotted on the vertical (y) axis and quantity on the horizontal (x) axis, following the mathematical convention established by Alfred Marshall.

questions.question: The difference between a 'change in supply' and a 'change in quantity supplied' is that:
options: A change in supply involves movement along the curve, while a change in quantity supplied shifts the curve
A change in supply shifts the curve, while a change in quantity supplied involves movement along the curve
Both terms mean the same thing
Only quantity supplied can change, supply is always fixed
questions.explanation: A change in supply refers to a shift of the entire supply curve due to non-price factors. A change in quantity supplied refers to movement along the curve due to price changes.

questions.question: If the number of producers in a market increases, the market supply curve will:
questions.explanation: More producers means more total production capacity at each price level, increasing overall market supply and shifting the supply curve to the right.

questions.question: A perfectly inelastic supply curve would appear on a graph as:
questions.explanation: Perfectly inelastic supply means quantity supplied does not change at all when price changes, represented by a vertical supply curve.

questions.question: If producers expect prices to rise significantly in the future, current supply will:
questions.explanation: Expectations of future price increases encourage producers to reduce current supply and wait to sell when prices are higher, shifting the current supply curve to the left.

questions.question: The area above the supply curve but below the market price represents:
questions.explanation: Producer surplus is the difference between what producers receive (market price) and the minimum they would accept (shown by the supply curve), represented by the area above the supply curve but below the price.

questions.question: If government subsidies reduce production costs for solar panels, the supply curve for solar panels will:
questions.explanation: Subsidies effectively lower production costs, making producers willing to supply more at each price level, shifting the supply curve to the right.

questions.question: The short-run supply curve is typically more inelastic than the long-run supply curve because:
options: Producers can't quickly adjust their production capacity
Consumers are less responsive in the short run
Prices are fixed in the short run
questions.explanation: In the short run, producers face fixed factors of production and cannot easily expand capacity, making supply less responsive to price changes.

questions.question: If taxes on production increase, the supply curve will:
questions.explanation: Taxes increase production costs, reducing the quantity producers are willing to supply at each price, shifting the supply curve to the left.

questions.question: A supply curve that becomes flatter indicates:
questions.explanation: A flatter supply curve indicates greater price elasticity - quantity supplied is more responsive to price changes.

questions.question: The main determinants of supply that shift the supply curve include all EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: The good's own price causes movement along the supply curve. The other factors are supply shifters that move the entire curve.

questions.question: The law of supply holds true because producers:
options: Always want to maximize consumer satisfaction
Face increasing opportunity costs as they produce more
Are required by law to increase output when prices rise
questions.explanation: As producers increase output, they typically use resources that are less suited to that production (increasing opportunity costs), so they require higher prices to justify producing additional units.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered the law of supply and understand producer behavior and the factors that influence production decisions.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basic concept but review the difference between movements along the supply curve versus shifts of the supply curve.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: Law of supply = price up, quantity up; Movement along curve = price change; Shift of curve = other factors change.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember the law of supply: when price increases, quantity supplied increases, and when price decreases, quantity supplied decreases.
